newsitem.title: UK: Poland deserves higher credit rating - c.bank chief.
newsitem.headline: Poland deserves higher credit rating - c.bank chief.

text.p: Poland, which plans an international debt issue this summer, deserves a higher credit rating, central bank President Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz said on Tuesday.

The leading U.S. rating agencies Moody's Investor Services and Standard and Poor's are conducting routine reviews of Poland in April and May, although the Finance Ministry has said no change will automatically follow.
Asked whether an upgrading was justified, Gronkiewicz-Waltz told Reuters: "Yes, the (economic) situation is better than two years ago."
But she declined to forecast whether an upgrade would actually materialise. She was speaking in London during the annual meeting of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Moody's awarded Poland an investment grade Baa3 rating in 1995 and did not change it last year. Standard and Poor's raised Poland to an investment grade BBB minus from a speculative BB given in 1995.
Poland is one of the fastest growing economies in Europe, with gross domestic product forecast to expand about 5.5 percent this year after about six percent in 1996 and seven percent in 1995.
Inflation has also fallen to about 16.5 percent from more than 20 percent a year ago but the current account deficit and credit growth are rising sharply .
The Polish government is planning a $300 million yankee bond issue this year.
